title: 105_s448
content: The "Local Government Interstate Waste Control Act" is cited as the short title. It amends the Solid Waste Disposal Act by adding a new section regarding interstate transportation and disposal of municipal solid waste. The "Local Government Interstate Waste Control Act" prohibits out-of-state municipal solid waste disposal or incineration in a State without authorization from the affected local government. The "Local Government Interstate Waste Control Act" requires formal authorization from affected local governments before accepting out-of-state municipal solid waste. Authorization must be granted at a meeting, recorded in writing, and considered final. The "Local Government Interstate Waste Control Act" mandates affected local governments to require specific information from facility owners seeking authorization to handle municipal solid waste. This information must be made available for inspection by the Governor, adjoining local governments, Indian tribes, and other interested parties. The facility owner must provide information on the anticipated waste quantities, facility site map, including buffer zones and all facility units. The owner or operator must provide details on buffer zones and facility units, environmental characteristics of the site, including groundwater resources, and environmental controls to be used on the site. The owner or operator must provide details on environmental controls to be used on the site, including runoff management, air pollution control devices, methane monitoring, landfill covers, liners, leachate collection systems, and waste residuals management. The owner or operator must provide a description of waste residuals generated by the facility, site access controls, roadway improvements, permits needed, and personnel requirements. The owner or operator must provide information on waste residuals, site access controls, roadway improvements, permits, and personnel requirements, including skill and education levels needed for jobs at the facility. The facility must provide information on environmental law violations, enforcement proceedings, corrective actions, rehabilitation measures, and gifts/contributions as required by State law. The facility must provide information on gifts, contributions, compliance with state solid waste management plan, and notification prior to formal action. Prior to formal action on granting authorization for out-of-State municipal solid waste, affected local government must notify Governor, adjoining local governments, and Indian tribes, publish notice in newspaper before holding a hearing. The local government must notify the Governor, adjoining local governments, and any relevant parties before holding a public hearing for public comment on the action. The local government must notify the Governor, adjoining local governments, and any adjoining Indian tribes of an authorization granted under State law. Limitations apply to landfills and incinerators in operation or under construction. The owner or operator of a landfill or incinerator must have received out-of-State municipal solid waste shipments or obtained documented authorization before the enactment of this section. The owner or operator of a landfill or incinerator must have legally binding authorization from the local government to accept out-of-State municipal solid waste. The facility must comply with all relevant Federal and State laws regarding design, location, leachate collection, groundwater monitoring, and financial assurance. The owner or operator of a landfill or incinerator must have legal authorization to accept out-of-State municipal solid waste. The facility must comply with applicable requirements of the Clean Air Act and State laws for facility design. Documentation of waste shipments is required for compliance. The owner or operator of a landfill or incinerator must provide documentation of waste shipments to the Governor of the State. Governors have the authority to restrict out-of-state municipal solid waste disposal at landfills upon written requests from affected local governments and solid waste planning units. Governors can limit out-of-state municipal solid waste disposal at landfills upon written requests from affected local governments and solid waste planning units. The landfill referred to in clause (i) shall be a landfill in the State, the owner or operator of which is exempt from certain requirements. Prior to submitting a request to limit the disposal of out-of-State municipal solid waste, an affected local government and solid waste planning unit must provide notice, opportunity for public comment, and follow procedural requirements. The Governor must respond consistently to requests from affected local governments regarding the disposal of out-of-State municipal solid waste, without discrimination based on specific landfills or the origin state of the waste. The Governor must respond consistently to requests from affected local governments regarding the disposal of out-of-State municipal solid waste, without discrimination based on specific landfills or the origin state of the waste. The Governor's authority is limited if it conflicts with State law or existing contracts for waste disposal. The section does not affect existing agreements or state laws, and requires the owner or operator of a landfill to make contracts available for public inspection in the affected community. The owner or operator of a landfill must make contracts for out-of-State waste disposal available for public inspection in the affected community. Proprietary information can be redacted, but details like waste volume, source, and contract duration must be visible. The section outlines the applicability of the contract requirements to each State, with an option for States to become exempt by notifying the Administrator and making specific reference to the section. The section allows States to be exempt from contract requirements by notifying the Administrator and referencing the section. The Administrator will acknowledge the exemption upon receipt of the notification. Definitions include "affected local government" as elected officials of a city, town, borough, or county. The term 'government' in relation to a landfill or incinerator refers to elected officials with primary jurisdiction over the facility's location. 'Affected local solid waste planning unit' is a political subdivision with authority over solid waste management planning. 'Host agreement' is a legally binding agreement entered into lawfully. Management planning in accordance with State law includes a host agreement, which is a legally binding agreement between a landfill or incinerator owner/operator and an affected local government. Municipal solid waste refers to refuse generated by the general public. Municipal solid waste is solid waste generated by the general public or from various sources, consisting of paper, wood, yard wastes, food wastes, plastics, leather, rubber, and other materials. Exclusions include hazardous waste, industrial waste, and medical waste. The curr_chunk discusses the types of materials that are excluded from municipal solid waste, including polychlorinated biphenyls, industrial waste, medical waste, recyclable materials separated from waste, and materials returned to manufacturers. The curr_chunk defines terms related to waste management, such as out-of-state municipal solid waste and owner or operator of a landfill or incinerator. The curr_chunk specifies exclusions for landfill or incinerator ownership, including state or local government ownership within their jurisdiction and facilities receiving waste only from the owner. Interstate transportation and disposal of municipal solid waste is addressed in Sec. 4011.
